Authors: Nursanti T.D., Masruroh, Dwi Irvianti L.S.
Title: The relationship between socio-economic backgrounds and intrepreneurial characteristics
Source title: Pertanika Journal of Social Sciences and Humanities
Affiliations: Management Department, BINUS Business School Undergraduate Program, Bina Nusantara University (BINUS), Jakarta Barat, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Nursanti, T.D., Management Department, BINUS Business School Undergraduate Program, Bina Nusantara University (BINUS), Jakarta Barat, 11480, Indonesia; Masruroh, Management Department, BINUS Business School Undergraduate Program, Bina Nusantara University (BINUS), Jakarta Barat, 11480, Indonesia; Dwi Irvianti, L.S., Management Department, BINUS Business School Undergraduate Program, Bina Nusantara University (BINUS), Jakarta Barat, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: The purpose of this research is to identify the socioeconomic backgrounds of women traders in the traditional markets in West Jakarta. In addition, it also aims to find about the entrepreneurial characteristics of the women traders and to determine the relationship between their socioeconomic backgrounds and their entrepreneurial characteristics. The research used associative method with the primary data obtained through interviews and questionnaires distributed to 72 women traders as respondents. The secondary data was obtained through literature review. Data was subjected to factor analysis and then correlated to each other. The results show that in general the correlation between the components of socioeconomic backgrounds and entrepreneurial characteristics of the women traders was very low, as indicated by a score below 0.5. Among the lowest correlation scores, the highest was the correlation score between age (in socioeconomic backgrounds) and leadership (entrepreneurial characteristics) with a score of 0.279, which means age had 27.9% correlation to leadership. Therefore, it can be concluded that the older the women traders, the higher the level of their leadership. © Universiti Putra Malaysia Press.
Author Keywords: Entrepreneurial characteristics; Socioeconomic backgrounds; Traditional markets; Women traders
References: Chavez, G., Entrepreneurial characteristics amongst women microentrepreneurs (2005) Paliparan. Dasmarinas, Cavite, , De La Salle University; Creswell, J.W., (2002) Educational Research: Planning, Conducting, and Evaluating Quantitative, pp. 146-166. , Upper Saddle River, NJ: Prentice Hall; Littunen, H., Entrepreneurship and the characteristics of the entrepreneurial personality (2000) International Journal of Entrepreneurial Behaviour & Research, 6 (6), pp. 295-310; (2007) Modern Markets Hurt Traditional Markets: Traditional Market Growth Decreased for 8.1 Percent, , www.republika.co.id, Retrieved October 15, 2016, from; Ruswanti, E., Education entrepreneurship, training hair cut of entrepreneurial motivation (2016) International Journal of Economics and Management, 10 (S1), pp. 167-181; Santoso, S., (2014) Statistik Nonparametrik: Konsep Dan Aplikasi Dengan SPSS (Edisi Revisi), , Jakarta: Elex Media Komputindo

Title: Gender effect in moderating personal factor influence on job satisfaction of lecturer binus university, jakarta, indonesia
Source title: Pertanika Journal of Social Sciences and Humanities
Affiliations: School of Business Management, Binus University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Masruroh, School of Business Management, Binus University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Nursanti, T.D., School of Business Management, Binus University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Irvianti, L.S.D., School of Business Management, Binus University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: The phenomenon of woman in labour is pushing a lot of research on gender in the workplace. This study was conducted to determine the role of gender in moderating the influence of personal factors among lecturers in the college sector. This research took place at a private university in Jakarta, namely Bina Nusantara University. By using path analysis method for analysing data based on questionnaires that were distributed to 100 lecturers. Results show that personal factors influencing job satisfaction among lecturers were not affected by the gender issues. These findings are the same as those found by Kaiser (2005).
Author Keywords: Gender; Job Satisfaction; Lecturer; Personal Factor
References: (2014) Our People, Our Focus: Inclusion & Diversity at Accenture, , https://acnprod.accenture.com/_acnmedia/Accenture/Conversion-Assets/DotCom/Documents/About-Accenture/PDF/1/Accenture-Our-People-Our-Focus-Inclusion-Diversity-2014.pdf, Accenture [online]. Title: The influence of organizational justice on organizational citizenship behavior with perceived organizational support as mediator
Affiliations: School of Business Management, Binus University11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Masruroh, School of Business Management, Binus University11480, Indonesia; Wijaya, I., School of Business Management, Binus University11480, Indonesia; Nursanti, T.D., School of Business Management, Binus University11480, Indonesia
Abstract: This research was conducted at the Neglasari subdistrict office. It is located in the city of Tangerang, Tangerang District, Banten Province. The purpose of this study was to determine whether there is an influence of Organizational Justice on Organizational Citizenship Behavior with Perceived Organizational Support as a mediator variable. All public servants (PNS) at the sub-district office of Neglasari are object of research. Data obtained by questionnaire spread to all public servants (70 people) at Neglasari subdistrict office. The analytical method used was path analysis. Based on the research results, the variable Perceived Organizational Support successfully mediated the influence of Organizational Justice on Organizational Citizenship Behavior, in other words, Perceived Organizational Support strengthening the effect Organizational Justice on Organizational Citizenship. This means that if an organization wants to improve Organizational Citizenship Behavior of public servant, the organization needs to improve Organizational Justice, in addition to increasing the Organizational Justice, the organization also must improve Perceived Organization Support in order to reinforce the Organizational Citizenship Behavior of public servants at Neglasari subdistrict office, Kota Tangerang. © 2015 American Scientific Publishers. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Organizational citizenship behavior; Organizational justice; Perceived organizational support; Sub-district Neglasari
References: Chegini, M.G., (2009) American Journal of Economics and Bussiness Administration, 1, p. 171; Fatdina, D., (2009) HUMANITAS (Jurnal Psikologi Indonesia), 6, p. 74; Ince, M., Gül, H., (2011) International Journal of Business and Management, 6, p. 134; Janssen, O., (2004) Journal of Organizational Behavior, 25, p. 201; Khan, S., Rashid, M.Z., (2012) International Journal of Business and Social Sciences, 3, p. 83; Mohammad, J., Habib, F.Q., Alias, M.A., (2011) Asian Academy of Management Journal, 16, p. 149; Noruzy, A., Shatery, K., Rezazadeh, A., Hatami-Shirkouhi, L., (2011) Indian Journal of Science and Technology, p. 842; Paillé, P., Bourdeau, L., Galois, I., (2010) International Journal of Organizational Analysis, 18, p. 41; Ristig, K., (2009) Management Research News, 32, p. 659; Robbins, S.P., Coulter, M.K., (2009) Organisations and Behaviour Pearson Custom Pub; Sekaran, U., Dan Bougie, R., (2010) Research Methods for Business, , Fifth edn., United Kingdom, Wiley; Organ, D.W., Podsakoff, P.M., Mackenzie, S.P., (2006) Organizational Citizenship Behavior: Its Nature, Antecedents, and Consequences, , Sage Publications, London
